]]> Alison Kodjak White House Request For Emergency Zika Funding Hits Roadblock In Congress The Obama administration requested $1.9 billion in emergency funding to prepare against the Zika virus. Congressional Republicans say the administration doesn't need all that money now and insist the White House is asking for a blank check. Thu, 12 May 2016 16:30:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835957/white-house-request-for-emergency-zika-funding-hits-roadblock-in-congress?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835957/white-house-request-for-emergency-zika-funding-hits-roadblock-in-congress?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health The Obama administration requested $1.9 billion in emergency funding to prepare against the Zika virus. Congressional Republicans say the administration doesn't need all that money now and insist the White House is asking for a blank check.

]]> Ailsa Chang Researchers Offer Jet Lag Advice In Return For Data About Your Sleep Users of an app developed by the University of Michigan to help with jet lag entered information on their time zone and sleep patterns that helped academics with their work. But is the approach valid? Thu, 12 May 2016 12:42:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/05/12/477526340/researchers-offer-jet-lag-advice-in-return-for-data-about-your-sleep?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/05/12/477526340/researchers-offer-jet-lag-advice-in-return-for-data-about-your-sleep?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health Users of an app developed by the University of Michigan to help with jet lag entered information on their time zone and sleep patterns that helped academics with their work. But is the approach valid?

]]> Alan Yu Look, Ma! No Mitochondria Scientists have found the first eukaryotic organism that functions fine without mitochondria, the "powerhouses" that make energy for the cells of yeast, humans and other animals. Thu, 12 May 2016 12:11:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/05/12/477691018/look-ma-no-mitochondria?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/05/12/477691018/look-ma-no-mitochondria?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health Scientists have found the first eukaryotic organism that functions fine without mitochondria, the "powerhouses" that make energy for the cells of yeast, humans and other animals.

]]> Nell Greenfieldboyce DIY Blood Tests? There's A Downside To Ordering Your Own It's legal to order diagnostic blood tests without consulting a doctor in many states. But critics say healthy patients can go down a rabbit hole of invasive assays and unnecessary treatments. But critics say healthy patients can go down a rabbit hole of invasive assays and unnecessary treatments.

]]> Jon Brooks Selling Health Insurance Across State Lines Sounds Good, But Is It? ]]> Michaeleen Doucleff Public Health Professor: Because Of Zika, Rio Olympics 'Must Not Proceed' If half a million tourists go to Rio, there is a risk one could catch Zika, return home and seed a new outbreak, says public health professor Amir Attaran. ]]> NPR Staff Presidential Candidates Confront Obstacles To Opioid Addiction Treatment Presidential candidates have been confronted by voters over the crisis of opioid abuse and heroin addiction. ]]> Tamara Keith Meet The Tiny Critters Thriving In Your Carpet, Kitchen And Bed Dust mites, gall wasps and book lice don't bite, but they might make you wheeze. Scientists found about 100 types of arthropods wiggling or munching skin flakes in typical homes. Take a look. ]]> Josh Cassidy State Insurance Mandates For Autism Treatment Fall Short Most states require insurers to pay for autism treatments. But that hasn't done much to get therapy to children who need it, a study finds. It's important to get treatment as early as possible. Wed, 11 May 2016 10:15:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/05/11/477623384/state-insurance-mandates-for-autism-treatment-fall-short?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/05/11/477623384/state-insurance-mandates-for-autism-treatment-fall-short?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health Most states require insurers to pay for autism treatments. But that hasn't done much to get therapy to children who need it, a study finds. It's important to get treatment as early as possible.

]]> Shefali Luthra When Time Behind Bars Cuts Addiction Treatment Short Most inmates lose access to medication-assisted treatment for addiction once they're incarcerated. Among prisons and jails that do offer such treatment, it's often restricted to pregnant women. Wed, 11 May 2016 09:16:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/05/11/476920122/when-time-behind-bars-cuts-addiction-treatment-short?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/05/11/476920122/when-time-behind-bars-cuts-addiction-treatment-short?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health Most inmates lose access to medication-assisted treatment for addiction once they're incarcerated. Among prisons and jails that do offer such treatment, it's often restricted to pregnant women.

]]> Why The FDA Is Re-Evaluating The Nutty Definition Of 'Healthy' Food Under current rules, foods containing more than 3 grams of fat per serving can't call themselves "healthy" on labels. But that excludes many foods, like Kind bars, that contain healthful nuts. Tue, 10 May 2016 17:05:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2016/05/10/477514200/why-the-fda-is-reevaluating-the-nutty-definition-of-healthy-food?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2016/05/10/477514200/why-the-fda-is-reevaluating-the-nutty-definition-of-healthy-food?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=health Under current rules, foods containing more than 3 grams of fat per serving can't call themselves "healthy" on labels. But that excludes many foods, like Kind bars, that contain healthful nuts.

]]> Allison Aubrey Peggy Girshman Gets The Last Word On Health Journalism Veteran NPR editor Peggy Girshman, who died in March, wrote her own eulogy, which included personal health advice and tips for better journalism.
